title: About Me
text:
I‚Äôm Ethan Long, an aspiring data scientist from Boston currently pursuing a B.S. in Statistics at the University of Connecticut (Class of 2026).
I‚Äôm passionate about using data to solve problems, tell stories, and drive smarter decisions ‚Äî whether through predictive modeling, hypothesis testing, or visual analytics. My academic journey and hands-on projects have prepared me to work with large datasets, build models, and deliver clear insights.



Sports Analytics

Machine Learning & AI

Public Policy & Government Data

Predictive Modeling

ETL and Data Pipelines





Clutch Gene (2025): MLB postseason performance analysis using OPS, TB, and cWPA.
NYC 311 Service Requests: Explored and analyzed 311 flooding complaints throughout NYC.
NYC Crash Data: Cleaned & analyzed 500k+ crash records to find top contributors to severe crashes.
Loan Approval Model: Built a stepwise logistic model in R using 700k+ mortgage applications.




Languages & Tools: Python, R, SQL, SAS, Tableau, Excel, scikit-learn, Statsmodels, ggplot2
Techniques: Regression, Hypothesis Testing, Feature Engineering, Predictive Modeling, ETL, Web Scraping

Location: Boston, MA

title: Ethan Long ‚Äì Data Science Portfolio
text:
I‚Äôm a junior at the University of Connecticut studying Statistics, with a strong focus on data science, predictive modeling, and sports analytics.
This portfolio highlights academic projects where I‚Äôve applied Python, R, SQL, and machine learning to solve real-world problems ‚Äî from predicting MLB player performance to analyzing NYC crash data.


Clutch Gene: Quantifying Performance Under Pressure in Baseball
An analysis of MLB postseason vs.¬†regular season performance using statistical testing, clustering, and logistic regression.
NYC 311 Flooding - Complaint Trends Dashboard ` Mapped and modeled flooding complaints in NYC to identify high-risk areas and recurring seasonal patterns.
This site is built with Quarto.

title: Quantifying Clutchness ‚Äì A Data-Driven Analysis of Performance Under Pressure in Professional Baseball
text:
The concept of ‚Äúclutchness‚Äù in professional baseball has long been debated, yet remains difficult to quantify. This study aims to investigate whether high-pressure situations influence player performance and whether distinct ‚Äúclutch‚Äù archetypes exist. Using regular season and postseason data from Baseball Reference, we analyze three key performance metrics: On-Base Plus Slugging (OPS), Total Bases (TB), and Championship Win Probability Added (cWPA)‚Äîto assess how players respond under varying levels of pressure. We employ hypothesis testing to determine statistical significance in performance differences, K-means clustering for classifying players into specific archetypes, and logistic regression models to forecast probability of success in high-leverage situations. By integrating statistical analysis with sabermetrics, this study seeks to provide a data-driven perspective on the existence of a ‚Äúclutch gene‚Äù in baseball. Our findings could have implications for player evaluation, recruitment strategies, and in-game decision-making, offering a more objective framework for understanding performance under pressure. Using regular season and postseason data from Baseball Reference, we analyze three key metrics:

On-Base Plus Slugging (OPS)

Total Bases (TB)

Championship Win Probability Added (cWPA)

We apply hypothesis testing, clustering, and logistic modeling to uncover patterns in high-leverage performance.

title: Quantifying Clutchness ‚Äì A Data-Driven Analysis of Performance Under Pressure in Professional Baseball

title: Quantifying Clutchness ‚Äì A Data-Driven Analysis of Performance Under Pressure in Professional Baseball
text:
GitHub Repository


This project investigates whether Major League Baseball players perform differently under high-pressure situations compared to low-pressure situations. It explores the idea of a ‚Äúclutch gene‚Äù ‚Äì the potential for players to rise or fall in high-leverage situations.
By analyzing detailed performance metrics and applying statistical techniques, this study seeks to objectively evaluate ‚Äúclutchness‚Äù and classifyplayer archetypes that emerge under pressure




Baseball Reference - Regular Seasons & Postseason stats (2021 & 2023)
Metrics Analyzed :

On-Base Plus Slugging (OPS)
Total Bases (TB)
Championship Winning Probability Added (cWPA)






Python: pandas, NumPy, scikit-learn, statsmodels

Statistical Testing: Paired sample t-tests

Machine Learning: K-Means Clustering

Modeling: Logistic Regression to predict postseason performance shifts

Visualization: PCA plots, delta histograms, performance cluster maps





Statistically significant performance differences were found between regular and postseason play.
Players exhibited distinct archetypes, including ‚ÄúPostseason Risers‚Äù and ‚ÄúOctober Collapsers.‚Äù
Logistic models showed modest but directional predictive power for high-pressure success indicators.







Full Poster





K-Means Clustering of Player Archetypes

title: NYC 311 Flooding Complaints Analysis
text:
GitHub Repository


This project analyzes 311 complaints in New York City related to flooding, with the goal of identifying spatial and temporal patterns. It highlights which neighborhoods and time periods experience the most flooding issues, helping inform city resource planning and infrastructure development.




NYC Open Data - 311 Service Request Database
Filtered to complaints regarding ‚ÄúStreet Flooding‚Äù or ‚ÄúBasin Flooding‚Äù

title: NYC 311 Flooding Complaints Analysis
text: This project analyzes 311 complaints in New York City related to flooding, with the goal of identifying spatial and temporal patterns. It highlights which neighborhoods and time periods experience the most flooding issues, helping inform city resource planning and infrastructure development.

title: NYC 311 Flooding Complaints Analysis
text:
NYC Open Data - 311 Service Request Database
Filtered to complaints regarding ‚ÄúStreet Flooding‚Äù or ‚ÄúBasin Flooding‚Äù

title: NYC 311 Flooding Complaints Analysis
text:
Key Insights

Flooding complaints are seasonally concentrated in summer and fall.
Complaints are most common in coastal and low-lying areas, especially parts of Brooklyn and Queens.
Several ZIP codes appear consistently in top complaint volumes, suggesting persistent infrastructure challenges.
